page.title: 10LOCAL HISTORY OF SANDHEAD
page.content: by Kenneth Rowan aged 12 One site of particular interest in our village is a large raised circle of soil called a "motte". Local historians are of differing opinions as to the origins of this motte, one of a number on the Rhinns of Galloway, but I like the one that says they were Pictish forts set up to defend the tribes against marauding Vikings in the 7th and 8th Centuries A.D.. There is also an old ruin in the middle of Balgreggan Wood. It belonged to the Maitlands but, when they died the house went to their cousin, a Miss Weir, who was very generous to the community of Sandhead village. She did not live in the house and it was used by the R.A.F. during the war. After the war Miss Weir had the roof taken off to avoid paying rates. It fell into ruin and had to be pulled down.
